render.tex: \title{Domain \& Range of $f(x)$} What are they and how to find them?

reason.tex:
%text Just as a king has a domain (kingdom), a function has a domain The domain of $f(x)$ is the set of all values of $x$ for which $f(x)$ is defined \underline\text{Do not assume} that the domain for every $f(x)$ is $\mathbb{R}$. Some functions are defined in a narrower band of $x$, as shown below % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NNN}
\hline f(x) & \text{Not defined if} & \text{Domain} \\ \hline \frac{1}{x} & x = 0 & \mathbb{R} - \left\lbrace 0\right\rbrace \\ \hline \frac{1}{\sqrt{x+2}} & x + 2 \leq 0\text{ or } x \leq -2 & (-2,\infty) \\ \hline \frac{1}{x^2-1} & (x-1)\cdot(x+1) = 0 & \mathbb{R} - \left\lbrace -1,1\right\rbrace \\ \hline \log x & x \leq 0 & \mathbb{R}^+ \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text \underline\text{The range of a function} is simply the set of all values $f(x)$ can take in it's domain For example, $f(x) = \vert x\vert$ is defined for all $x\in\mathbb{R}$. But it can take only positive values. Hence, it's range is $\mathbb{R}^+$%
